awd_titl_txt: Numerical and Observational Studies of UTLS Potential Vorticity Dipoles in Midlatitude and Tropical Cyclones
awd_abstract_narration:
Midlatitude cyclones (MCs) and tropical cyclones (TCs) account for the major storms that greatly impact society. Their complex evolution can be influenced by atmospheric mesoscale motion in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere (UTLS). The investigator has found that strong convective updraft within these cyclones can induce counter rotating air circulations, known as potential vorticity (PV) dipoles, in the UTLS. Near the top of the storms, these dipoles create horizontal flow enhancement (or "jetlets") and strong perturbations that can significantly modify the storm evolution and precipitation amount. This study aims to examine these ULTS features related to MCs and TCs. Emerging results can improve our ability to forecast major storms, helping to minimize their impacts.
 
In particular, the negative anomaly of the PV dipole is inertially unstable and can promote precipitation and alter the evolution of mesoscale and synoptic systems. Coupled to the dipole orientation, the jetlets appear to form as a result of the difference in horizontal speed in the updraft compared to that of the surrounding UTLS air. The investigator hypothesizes that, in MCs, the jetlet will oppose the ambient flow, with the negative PV anomaly lying to the left of the flow. While in TCs, the jetlet will be in the same sense as lower tropospheric cyclonic flow, with the inertially-unstable member lying radially outward. To test this hypothesis, the proposal will carry out numerical and observational studies of the PV dipoles in the UTLS for a wide range of MC and TC cases, and will explore their dynamics, occurrence, and relationship with severe weather. The investigation will focus on four linked areas: (1) dynamics of PV dipoles, (2) climatological aspects of PV dipoles, (3) UTLS PV and extreme flooding events in the Upper Midwest, and (4) comparison of PV dipoles in mesoscale numerical simulations with auxiliary observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This work has provided new insight into the dynamics of the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere (UTLS), with a focus on mesoscale potential vorticity (PV) structures and their role in severe weather.  Three new contributions regarding the dynamics of meoscale PV structures are highlighted: 1) the formation of tropopause folds, 2) derecho outflow jets, and 3) the diurnal cycle of mesoscale PV variability in tropical cyclones (TCs).  We showed, for the first time, that derechos have a lower tropospheric PV dipole associated with the downdraft / updraft pair, and a southward outflow jet between.   We developed a new methodology for evaluating the mesoscale variability of UTLS PV in TCs following their storm tracks and found that there is a diurnal cycle with a maximum from midnight to sunrise and a minimum near sunset.  

1) START-08 aircraft data and numerical simulations with the University of Wisconsin Nonhydrostatic Modeling System (UWNMS) showed that tropopause folds associated with midlatitude cyclones are caused by vertical differences in horizontal wind, rather than a “circulation around the jet”.  A jet streak in the upper troposphere will override more slowly-moving air at lower altitudes, creating the pattern of a stratospheric intrusion (Fig. 1).  This work also showed that the strong gradient in ozone and other chemical constituents across westerly jets are created by convective injection of air with negative PV and low ozone into the UTLS on the equatorward side of the jet.

2)   The derecho of 10 August 2020 caused widespread damage across Iowa and Illinois.  Des Moines station data showed that the arrival of the gust front was characterized by an abrupt shift to northerly flow, exceeding 22 m/s for about 20 minutes. We investigated the structure of PV in the UWNMS and of absolute vorticity in High Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) forecast analyses.  This work describes the lower tropospheric horizontal PV dipole structure and its relationship with the outflow jet for the first time. The negative PV member coincides with the downdraft, while the positive PV member coincides with the updraft, with a northerly jet between (Figs. 2 and 3). The westerly inflow jet descends anticyclonically in the downdraft, joining with northerly flow from the surface anticyclone. The resulting northerly outflow jet creates the trailing comma-shaped radar echo of a derecho.  The speed of propagation of the derecho is similar to the westerly wind maximum in the 3-5 km layer associated with the approaching synoptic cyclone, which acts as a steering level for resonant amplification.  This PV dipole structure contributes toward the dynamical stability and longevity of a derecho.

3)  Means and standard deviations of PV were calculated using 9 km ECMWF analyses following the storm track of TC Yasa, which occurred near Fiji in December 2020. A robust diurnal cycle in cloud-top PV variability was found, with a minimum near sunset and maximum overnight (Fig. 4). When Yasa reached intensity C2, the maximum shifted from 6 am to midnight, and there was a reduction in cloud-top PV variability by a factor of two. This work contributes toward understanding dynamical adjustment and rapid intensification in TCs.

ECMWF 9 km operational forecast analyses of PV were used to explore the diurnal cycle of 15 Gulf Coast TCs during 2020 – 2022.  Using the annulus geometry, it was shown that the maximum in 100 hPa PV variability does not propagate radially outward. The diurnal cycle for storm strength of category C2 or stronger maximizes around midnight (Fig. 5), significant at the 95% level.  A weaker diurnal cycle was observed for C1 or weaker TCs, with maxima closer to sunrise.  The inner ring of mature hurricanes showed a statistically significant diurnal cycle, with peak near midnight.

We also analyzed 20 South Pacific TCs during 2016-2021.  A significant diurnal cycle in the mesoscale variability of 100 hPa PV was found,  peaking in the inner core of strong TCs peaks at midnight, while the peak tends to occur near sunrise in developing TCs and in the outer portion of TCs (Fig. 6).  These results support theories of the diurnal cycle in cloud radiative forcing, where the “cloud greenhouse effect” for continuous convection in a balanced vortex peaks near midnight. Cloud radiative forcing peaks near sunrise for patchy convection, due to the differences between radiative cooling in clear versus cloudy areas. 

This work provides a complementary approach to understanding TC dynamics and contributes toward improved understanding of rapid intensification and dynamical adjustment toward balance in TCs.  These new methods and results provide the basis for an array of future work on the dynamics and climatology of mesoscale PV variability in TCs for each world basin.

This grant has provided professional development opportunities for the graduate research assistants and Researcher II, including enhanced skills in data analysis, statistics, visualization software, theoretical interpretation, designing projects, posing hypotheses, defining objectives, and communicating results.
